South Summit School District is seeking applications for a part-time library media specialist at South Summit Elementary School. This position will be 17.5 hours per week.
Salary will be based on the 2020-2021 Classified Salary Schedule and will receive no benefits.
Qualified applicants must be organized and have a positive, compassionate attitude and maintain good relationships with staff, students, and parents. Responsibilities include managing the school media center and teaching library skills to K-4th grade students. Applicants must be fingerprinted and satisfactorily pass an employment background check.
Classified applications are available online www.ssummit.org
For best consideration, please submit applications by September 25, 2020. Submit application, resume, and any relevant documents to the South Summit District Office, 285 E 400 S Kamas, UT 84036, or email to ljosie@ssummit.org Please direct questions to Principal Lisa Flinders at 435-640-8932.
South Summit School District is an Equal Opportunity Employer.

Additionally, Savannah has volunteered this past year at the Elementary School, was a co-conductor for Pat Jones's Children's Choir and volunteered at the After-School Program.

Congratulations, Savannah!

Myth: Shut off your natural gas
Fact: Only shut it off if you hear or smell gas escaping.

Myth: Get in a doorway.
Fact: It's better to get under a table or desk.

Best,

Superintendent Shad E. Sorenson

post_text: Did you know that burning 10 lbs. of wood for one hour, releases as much PAHs (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons) as 6,000 packs of cigarettes? Wood burning may smell good but, many preventable health problems can be causes by frequent wood burning. The Burn Smart program offered by the Summit County Health Department, Habitat for Humanity, Purple Air and UPHE are helping residents replace wood burning heat sources with cleaner options. This program can cover between $250 and $4,000 of the actual costs depending on factors such as income level and individual project complexity. If you live in Summit County and have a wood burning heat source you may qualify for compensation. Learn more and apply for the program at summitcountyhealth.org/burn-smart

I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause.

Unofficial results from the Summit County Clerk's Office show the bond was defeated, 1,304 to 1,181. A message from Superintendent Sorenson follows:

"Our vision is to value individuals and prepare them for success. Despite the community's vote to not bond, our commitment to preparing our students for college and career readiness will not waiver. I am appreciative of the voices on both sides of the issue and certainly keeping communication open is critical as we work together to find solutions to manage growth. Overcrowding will continue to be an issue, but we'll do all we can to support, empower, and inspire individuals to promote and achieve academic and character excellence. The bond's failure means that we will begin to implement some short-term fixes most likely with portables and explore future bond proposals."

Parents,

Summit County Sheriff's Office asked all schools in Kamas to go into "Shelter in Place" this afternoon for a short amount of time, which means that normal activity within the school resumes, but nobody is allowed in or out of the schools. No students or staff were in danger and by keeping the doors locked and not allowing entrance from from the outside we continued to keep them safe.

The shelter in place was removed today at 2:25 p.m. and bus transportation resumed their regularly scheduled routes. Elementary students may be slightly delayed because of the delay leaving the school with secondary students.

We appreciate the partnership with our local law enforcement. Please contact the School District Office if you have any questions or concerns. (435) 783-4301.

The Board of Education is meeting tomorrow, Thursday (August 15) to decide whether to pass a resolution to bond for a new high school in November. They need your feedback regarding the potential bond.

Please come to the meeting or contact your board member to let them know whether you support a resolution to bond for a comprehensive new high school (including athletic fields and stadium), even if updated construction costs are more than anticipated. OR if you don't support a resolution to bond for a comprehensive new high school.
